I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  On 1 January 2001, Indonesia embarked on a major decentralization exercise. Key 
functions and institutions of the Government have to be altered to respond to the immense 
changes taking place. As decentralization should lead to balanced development, managing 
regional disparities in economic and poverty reduction programs is a major central government 
responsibility. The Government requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance during 
the 2001 Country Programming Mission to support an advisory technical assistance (ADTA) 
project to address this issue. An ADTA project—Managing Regional Disparity in Economic and 
Poverty Reduction Programs under Decentralization—was programmed for 2002. ADB staff 
undertook fact finding in June-November 2002, and reached a broad understanding with the 
Government on the project’s design and scope.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The  decentralization  program  has  devolved  vast  responsibilities  on  regional 
governments. Under Laws 22 and 25 of 1999, which underpin decentralization, other than 
foreign policy, defense, security, judiciary, monetary and fiscal matters, and religious affairs, 
almost all other matters are being devolved to regional2 governments in 31 provinces and about 
360 districts and cities. The primary responsibility to provide basic services as well as the 
national3 effort to reduce poverty will now mainly be their responsibility. However, the fiscal 
capacities of regional governments vary considerably, hindering the national effort to reduce 
poverty. Many governments in regions with large numbers of poor have inadequate resources to 
accelerate overall development, particularly in rural areas, and to reduce poverty and continue 
the previous central government-assisted efforts begun before decentralization.  
 
3.  Wide  disparity  exists  among  regional  governments  in  poverty  reduction,  human 
development, and access to development resources. Although Indonesia made rapid progress 
in poverty reduction before the Asian economic crisis, incidence of poverty sharply increased 
during the crisis. The 1999 National Socio-Economic Survey (SUSENAS) revealed that 23.5% 
of the population was poor (current estimates are 17%). Recent data indicate that, nationally, 
real wages are at about 20% below the precrisis levels, suggesting persistent poverty. As part of 
its  geographical  focus  strategy  for  Indonesia, ADB found considerable disparity in poverty 
incidence, human development, and access to financial resources among regions. Before 
decentralization,  the  central  government  directly  addressed  this  issue,  particularly  poverty 
reduction, through a nationally  driven effort that focused on rapid and sustained growth of 
agriculture, high growth in nonagricultural sectors, high investments in human development, and 
targeted  poverty  programs.4  Under  decentralization,  the  coordinated  national  effort  might 
weaken, and institutional arrangements, particularly, might not be adequate to reduce economic 
and social disparities across regions.  
 
4.  The fiscal instruments available after decentralization to achieve equity in providing 
basic  services  and  reducing  economic  disparities  are  ineffective  and  insufficient.  The 
decentralization laws provide for revenue sharing under the General Allocation Fund (DAU), 
grant transfers under the Special Allocation Fund (DAK), and market borrowing by regional 
governments.  However,  due  to  the  absence  of  proper  guidelines  and  execution,  these

instruments are ineffective. Although the allocation formula for DAU, for instance, has strong 
features to support equity (such as weight on population and level of income), stipulations of 
Parliament that allocations received should not fall below the previous year's allocation have 
severely  limited  DAU’s  effectiveness.  DAK  guidelines  are  yet  to  be  finalized,  although 
allocations for 2003 have been made in some sectors. The regional borrowing instrument is not 
in  operation  as  the  central  government  has,  in  the  interest  of  fiscal  prudence,  placed  a 
temporary moratorium on the instrument’s use. The central government has not yet developed a 
framework for intergovernmental fiscal relations or a detailed policy of fiscal support to weaker 
regional governments for development and poverty reduction.  
 
5.  Law 22 of 1999 provides that national planning and national development should be 
central government responsibilities. The supporting regulations are being finalized by National 
Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS). Current thinking focuses mainly on coordination 
of national development goals and priorities with local ones, to be reflected ultimately in the 
main planning documents at the central and regional levels (National Development Program 
[PROPENAS],  Regional  Development  Program  [PROPEDA],  Regional  Strategic  Plan 
[RENSTRADA], Regional Annual Development Plan [REPETADA], etc.). Formal coordination 
meetings between agencies responsible for the various levels of planning have been prescribed 
at the district/city, provincial, and national levels through the Development Coordination Forums 
(RAKORBANG). The Government has so far held three large national RAKORBANG workshops 
since decentralization.5 Discussion has also begun on monitoring and evaluation of planning 
outcomes although nothing concrete has emerged. 
 
6.  The centralized planning system has to give way to one responsive to the challenges of 
decentralization.  However,  the  discourse  on  developing  a  new  system  of  central-regional 
development relationships could clearly benefit from insights into the following three main areas. 
 
7.  First, the planning and budgeting process at the regional level is not sufficiently geared 
to reduce poverty, and the consultative validation with the central government of strategic 
priorities–-particularly those that should be transformed into programs for implementation–-is 
weak. To begin with, these plans should be poverty oriented and realistic. Financing of the plans 
is not emphasized and the central government’s role in supporting regions’ pro-poor planning is 
not adequately defined. Although RAKORBANG provides for consultation, the process has not 
been sufficiently structured to yield meaningful results. This is partly because the end results of 
the consultations—the annual plans—are not sufficiently grounded on resource considerations 
and are, therefore, often unrealistic, making them inadequate tools for development and poverty 
reduction. The process also appears to need a higher degree of systematic technical evaluation 
of regional development plans and adequate representation of stakeholders such as civil society 
and the private sector.  
 
8.  Second, resource planning remains weak. The regional development strategies and 
annual plans are limited by lack of resources. The central government plays virtually no role in 
making resources available for priorities agreed upon at the regional level. Discussions on the 
architecture for intergovernmental fiscal relations are taking place independently of the planning 
process. So far, most discussions have centered around revenue sharing, and discussions 
beyond that on funding development (such as DAK) are at a preliminary stage (para. 4.) 
                                                 
5    A workshop of the Development Coordination Forum for central government agencies (RAKORBANGPUS) was 
also conducted in September 2002, emphasizing poverty  reduction, employment generation, development of 
lagging regions, and human resource development. The workshop also emphasized sharing information on 
central government budgetary allocations with regions.

3 
 
9.  Finally, the process pays no attention to a major central government responsibility: 
fostering regional balance and facilitating reduction of regional disparities by focusing on the 
needs  of  weaker  regions.  Regional  governments  with  insufficient revenues from revenue 
sharing and own revenue mobilization efforts will require assistance to generate development 
funds  for  high-priority  programs.  The  Committee  on  Poverty  Reduction  established  under 
Presidential Decree (Kepres) 124 of 2001 mandates BAPPENAS to develop basic policy on 
macro planning involving regional governments and other stakeholders. An area-based poverty 
profile has to be developed and all sources of funding—public, private, and from the financial 
sector—tapped.  The  committee  will  rely  on  the  Ministry  of  Home  Affairs  to  coordinate 
development programs at the regional level. This work may need to be coordinated with the 
ongoing development of the architecture for decentralized planning. 
 
10.  Although BAPPENAS is strongly committed to bring about improvements along the 
above lines, given the scale of work required, the central and regional governments should be 
prepared to address the problems mentioned. Central draft regulations for regional planning and 
budgeting are under development and must be supported. First, however, the ideas to be 
incorporated into these regulations need to be pilot-tested. Five poor regional governments will 
be selected under this TA for this purpose.  
 
11.  Although Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) and United States Agency for 
International  Development  (USAID)  provided  some  bilateral  support  for  some  aspects  of 
regional planning, they do not address the issue of achieving equity in the distribution of fiscal 
resources for fighting poverty. The ADTA’s support will fit in well with ADB's overall activities in 
support of decentralization, and the coordinated funding agencies' efforts in this area.6 Apart 
from  an  institutional  structure  for  decentralized  planning,  regional  governments  need 
considerable capacity building. A capacity-building project for regional governments, including in 
planning and development,7 is programmed for 2002 and can utilize the TA outputs. During TA 
implementation, learning from all relevant funding agency-assisted activities,8 past and ongoing, 
will be incorporated. 
 
III.  THE  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
12.  With  decentralization,  poor  regional  governments  have  little  capability  to  promote 
development and fight poverty. The TA’s goal is to support processes and/or procedures to 
improve pro-poor planning and develop recommendations for a national program of action to 
reduce regional disparities and poverty. The TA will identify pragmatic approaches to ensure 
that poor regions have adequate resources and support to deliver basic services and to pursue 
development programs, particularly in reducing poverty, to catch up with the better-off regions of 
the country. The TA will help the Government pilot-test policies and systems in one province, 
one city, and three districts (Appendix 1).

B.  Key Activities and Methodology 
13.  Central and regional government readiness to make planning and budgeting practices 
pro-poor is uncertain. A key outcome of this TA is an assessment of such readiness. The 
following activities are involved: 
 
(i)  Select  five  of  the  poorest  regional  governments  which  show  readiness  to 
undertake sound pro-poor planning and budgeting practices, and help them build 
capacity in these areas utilizing national and international best practices. 
(ii)  In  these  selected  regional  governments,  pilot-test  consultative  processes 
between  regional  and  central  governments  and  hold  consultations  with 
stakeholders such as civil society and the private sector. Develop best processes 
to ensure that local conditions are adequately reflected in the plans. Study the 
RAKORBANG process to improve its effectiveness so that it leads to a concrete 
validated  development  strategy,  agreed  between  the  central  and  selected 
regional governments, including agreements on minimum  quality of services 
provided through detailed annual inventory of projects and schemes based on 
technical analyses and clear annual budgeting of resources for development. 
Help the central government develop processes to validate these plans. 
(iii)  Based on needs of the five regions and their validated pro-poor plans, provide 
advice on financial support mechanisms from the regions’ own and outside 
sources to support the plans. Explore coordinating arrangements and the role of 
the central government in enabling regions to utilize the whole range of fiscal and 
other instruments to provide needed development resources, including grants 
through DAK, block loans from the center to the regions, external assistance, 
national schemes supported by cost-sharing between the center and the regions, 
national resource mobilization through market borrowings by regions facilitated 
by the center, improved provision of resources from the financial system for 
poverty reduction programs (such as microcredit), private sector participation, 
and participation by civil society.  
 
14.  Based on these regions’ experience, the TA will propose to the central government 
alternative development-cum-financing arrangements to support sustainable development and 
focus on reducing regional disparities and poverty, and enable the central government to finalize 
its draft regulations on regional planning under preparation. A follow-on ADTA (phase 2) will be 
prepared  to  utilize  the  experience  gathered  from  this  TA  to  make  national-level 
recommendations, particularly with respect to methods to determine if regional plans are pro-
poor, and to advise on mechanisms to identify and broker alternative funds for poor regions left 
with gaps in their resources to support pro-poor initiatives. Phase-II will also cover the issue of 
mechanisms to monitor expenditures to ensure that they achieve pro-poor outcomes. 
 
 
C.  Cost and Financing Plan 
15.  The total TA cost is estimated at $605,000 equivalent, of which $270,000 is the foreign 
exchange  cost  and  $335,000  equivalent  is  the  local  currency  cost.  The  Government  has 
requested ADB to finance $484,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost, and 
$214,000 equivalent of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed as a grant from the 
Government of the United Kingdom. The Government of Indonesia will bear the balance of 
$121,000 equivalent of the local currency cost by providing office facilities, administrative

5 
support,  and  remuneration  and  per  diem  of  counterpart  staff  and  their  local  transport 
(Appendix  2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The Executing Agency will be BAPPENAS (under the deputy minister for local autonomy 
and  regional  development).  A  steering  committee  will  be  established,  comprising 
representatives from the Offices of the Coordinating Ministers for the Economy and for Peoples' 
Welfare, Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Home Affairs, Committee on Poverty Reduction, the 
Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KADIN), civil society, and the five concerned regional 
governments. The steering committee members are expected to provide coordination and 
detailed advice to the consultants during the tripartite meetings based on the reports (para. 18) 
submitted to them before meetings. BAPPENAS, the EA, will establish a project management 
office (PMO), at least 1 month before the TA starts and keep it fully functional during TA 
implementation. One staff member at the appropriate level will be designated full-time to head 
the PMO and will be responsible for coordination, facilitation, and supervision of the consultants’ 
work. The EA will provide adequate administrative support for the consultants.  
 
17.  ADB will select and engage, using the simplified technical proposal, a firm or consortium 
of international and domestic consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. A 
total  of  12  person-months  of  international  and  24  person-months  of  domestic  experts  (in 
decentralized  planning  and  public  finance,  poverty  reduction  and  decentralization  law)  is 
anticipated to be required to implement the TA. The work of the consultants is expected to 
commence in March 2003 and continue for 8 months, the expected TA duration. The outline 
terms of reference of the consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
 
18.  Wide  stakeholder  consultations  (including  with  those  engaged  in  external  funding 
agency supported activities) through workshops will be essential. The consultants will prepare a 
brief inception report after the first fortnight, an interim report after the end of 4 months, a draft 
final report in the middle of the eighth month of the TA, and a final report at the end of the eighth 
month. These reports will be circulated in advance (at least 5 days before meetings) to steering 
committee members and discussed at tripartite meetings consisting of the Government (steering 
committee members), consultants, and ADB.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $484,000 to the Government 
of Indonesia to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom for 
Managing  Regional  Disparity  in  Economic  and  Poverty  Reduction  Programs  Under 
Decentralization (Phase 1), and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE OF CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants (12 person-months) 
  1.  Expert  on  Development  Strategy  and  Institutions  for  Decentralized 
Developing Economies/Team Leader (8 person-months) 
1.  The expert will have substantial expertise in public development planning, including at 
the regional level in developing countries, and have the following responsibilities:  
(i)  Coordinate all tasks of the team and be responsible for timely preparation and 
completion of all outputs. Coordinate with other external funding agencies and 
the Government.   
(ii)  Along  with  other  team  members,  assess  central  and  regional  government 
readiness to make planning and budgeting practices pro-poor. Help five regional 
governments develop capacity for pro-poor planning and budgeting. Organize 
training  for  staff  involved  in  regional  planning  and  budgeting.  Help  the  five 
regions prepare plans that have fully funded programs for regional development 
and poverty reduction.  
(iii)  Study the RAKORBANG process to improve its effectiveness so that it leads to a 
concrete agreed-on and validated development strategy, based on agreements 
with  the  central  government  and  other  stakeholders  on  minimum  quality  of 
services provided through detailed annual inventory of projects and schemes 
based  on  technical  analyses  and  clear  annual  budgeting  of  resources  for 
development. Pilot-test the consultative process between regional and central 
governments, and consultations with stakeholders such as civil society and the 
private sector. Help the central government develop processes to validate these 
plans. 
(iv)  Based on needs of the five regions and the validated pro-poor plans developed 
by  them,  and  in  consultation  with  the  international  specialist  in  public 
development financing, provide advice on financial support mechanisms from the 
regions’ own resources and from the central government to back the plans. 
(v)  Along with the other team members, utilize the experience of the five regions to 
advise National Development Planning Agency (BAPPENAS) on the policy and 
regulatory framework and operational guidelines on planning and budgeting for 
regional planning. 
  2.  Specialist on Public Development Financing in a Decentralized Context (4 
person-months) 
2.  The  specialist  will  have  experience  in  public  finance,  with  focus  on  development 
financing in a decentralized context, and be responsible for the following:  
(i)  Develop the financial support mechanisms to back the strategy and institutional 
arrangement being developed by the team leader and make it feasible.  
(ii)  Explore the whole range of fiscal instruments to provide needed development 
resources, including grants through the Special Allocation Fund (DAK), block 
loans from the center to the regions; external assistance, national schemes

supported by cost-sharing between the center and the regions, national resource 
raising  through  market  borrowings  by  the  regions  supported  by  central 
facilitation, improved provision of resources from the financial system for poverty 
reduction  programs  (such  as  microcredit);  coordination  of  private  sector 
participation;  and  coordination  of  participation  by  civil  society.  Examine 
possibilities of financial cooperation between regions, including mechanisms that 
allow flow of surplus funds from better-endowed regions to those that have a 
financial deficit.  
(iii)  Using the cases of the five regional governments, examine how to finance in a 
sustainable  fashion  the  development  of  poor  regions  and,  particularly,  their 
efforts to reduce poverty. The expert will recommend ways to optimize interaction 
among  regional  governments,  central  government,  private  sector,  and  other 
stakeholders to bring this about. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants (24 person-months) 
 
1.  Specialist on Indonesian Local/Regional Development (8 person-months) 
 
3.  The specialist will have extensive background in local/regional development planning, 
with substantial experience in working with regional governments in Indonesia. The specialist 
will support the team leader’s activities—(i) to (v)—to assess the readiness of regional and 
central governments and help develop the five regional governments’ capacity to prepare 
realistic, fully funded plans under the improved pro-poor processes. 
 
2.  Specialist on Poverty Reduction and Participatory Processes (8 person-
months) 
  
4.  The specialist will help the international consultants develop capacity in regions and 
processes for pro-poor planning, and in processes that assist in participatory planning, to 
ensure responsiveness to local needs.  
 
3.  Specialist in Indonesian Decentralization Law and Policy (8 person-months) 
 
5.  The main task of the specialist, who will be familiar with drafting regulations, will be to 
examine the legal and policy aspects of decentralization laws and recommend implementing 
regulations  based  on  the  Technical  Assistance  (TA)  team’s  recommendations  on  regional 
planning, and on the TA findings.  
     
C.  Workshops 
6.  To gain acceptance for the recommendations, several workshops are necessary. The 
number, types, and schedules of such workshops will be decided at the inception meeting. They 
will disseminate work in progress and recommendations as well as include learning from other 
relevant TAs, including Interim Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (IPRSP) TAs.  
D.  Reporting Requirements 
7.  The consultants will prepare a brief inception report 2 weeks after commencement, an 
interim report at the end of the fourth month, and a draft final report at the middle of the eighth 
month of the TA to be discussed at the final tripartite meeting. The final report will be presented

at the end of the eighth month after reflecting all comments at the final tripartite meeting. 
Reports will be circulated at least 5 days before meetings to members of the steering committee 
and discussed at tripartite meetings consisting of the Government (members of the steering 
committee), consultants, and the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Reporting formats will need 
prior ADB clearance.
